Usage

The general process of using reb4j consists of building up an expression from sub-expressions, then calling the toPattern method of the constructed expression in order to compile the expression.

Expressions are represented by the Regex class, instances of which are immutable after being constructed, which allows a single instance to be re-used as a sub-expression in many different expressions.

There is one sub-class, CharClass, which represents the specialized case of character classes (usually represented in regular expressions as ranges of characters surrounded by square brackets. Character classes (instances of CharClass) may be composed from other character classes, and larger expressions may be composed from character classes, but character classes cannot be composed from non-character class expressions (hence the need for a separate class to distinguish them).

Expression Types

reb4j provides the means to programmatically utilize any of the features of the java.util.regex.Pattern class. As such, there are many ways to build up regular expressions from their elemental parts.

Literals

The simplest type of sub-expression you are likely to need is a basic string match. reb4j makes this easy with the static Regex.literal method.

final Regex aBunchOfBracketsFollowedByAnA = Regex.literal("[[[[[A");

Notice that reb4j handles escaping characters that have special meaning in regular expressions, so you do not need to concern yourself with it.

Sequences

A common way to compose two or more expressions to is to define a sequence of expressions that are to appear in a particular order in the input. reb4j provides both a static and a non-static method for accomplishing this.

The non-static Regex.then method allows you to define a sequence of sub-expressions by chaining.

final Regex ab = Regex.literal("ab");
final Regex cd = Regex.literal("cd");
final Regex abcd = ab.then(cd);

However, the static Regex.sequence method is likely to be more convenient when dealing with sequences consisting of more than two sub-expressions.

final Regex a = Regex.literal("a");
final Regex b = Regex.literal("b");
final Regex c = Regex.literal("c");
final Regex d = Regex.literal("d");
final Regex abcd = Regex.sequence(a, b, c, d);

Alternation

Another common way to compose two or more expressions is to define alternates, with the composed expression representing the logical OR of the subexpressions. In regular expressions, this is indicated by the | character. In reb4j, it is accomplished using the Regex.or method, which comes in both static and non-static forms.

final Regex a = Regex.literal("a");
final Regex b = Regex.literal("b");
final Regex c = Regex.literal("c");
final Regex a_or_b = a.or(b); // using non-static version
final Regex a_or_b_or_c = Regex.or(a, b, c); // using static-version

Quantifiers

One of the most important features of regular expressions is the ability to indicate that a sub-expression may (or must) appear multiple times. This is expressed using quantifiers.

Kleene Star

The most fundamental type of quantifier is the Kleene Star, which is indicated by an asterisk (*) in most regular expression languages. It indicates that the preceding sub-expression may appear zero or more times in a row. reb4j supports this with the non-static Regex.star method.

final Regex a = Regex.literal("a");
final Regex zeroOrMore_a = a.star();
One or More

As an extension to the Kleene Star, most regular expression languages support a means to indicate that an expression must appear at least once. This is typically done with the plus (+) operator. reb4j provides support for this with the non-static Regex.atLeastOnce method.

final Regex a = Regex.literal("a");
final Regex a_repeating = a.atLeastOnce();
Optional

It is also possible to indicate that a sub-expression may appear exactly once or not at all, using the ? operator. reb4j provides for this with the Regex.optional method.

final Regex toBe = Regex.literal("to be");
final Regex toBeOrNotToBe = toBe.optional();
Bounded Repetition

The Pattern class allows for a specific number of repetitions or range of repetitions to be specified by enclosing the bounds in curly braces (), and in the case of a range of values, separating the minimum and maximum counts with a comma (,), possibly omitting either bound. reb4j supports all possibilities with a range of non-static methods.

The Regex.repeat(int) method can be used to specify an exact number of repetitions. Its overloaded form, Regex.repeat(int, int) can be used to indicate minimum and maximum numbers of repetitions.

The Regex.atLeast(int) method can be used to specify a minimum number of repetitions with no maximum.

Examples of the use of each of these are shown below.

final Regex a = Regex.literal("a");
final Regex a_4_times = a.repeat(4);
final Regex a_between_3_and_6_times = a.repeat(3, 6);
final Regex a_at_least_5_times = a.atLeast(5);
final Regex a_at_most_twice = a.repeat(0, 2);

Capturing Groups

The Pattern class allows you to indicate (using unqualified parentheses) sub-expressions that are to be used as "capturing groups". These groups are implicitly numbered in the order they appear in the regular expression, and, if they match, the segments of the input that matched each group can be independently obtained. To designate a sub-expression as a capturing group with reb4j, use the non-static group method. Be sure to pay attention to how your final expression is constructed. The groups will be numbered according to the order in which they begin in the final regular expression, which is not necessarily the same as the order you invoke the group method.

final Regex ABCs = Regex.literal("ABC").atLeastOnce();
final Regex oneTwoThrees = Regex.literal("123").atLeastOnce();
final Regex ABCsAndOneTwoThrees = ABCs.group().then(oneTwoThrees);
final Pattern pattern = ABCsAndOneTwoThrees.toPattern();
final Matcher matcher = pattern.matcher("ABCABCABC123123123");
if (matcher.matches())
{
        final String matchedABCs = matcher.group(1);
}

Character Classes

It is often necessary to define a sub-expression that will match many occurrences of any of a set of characters through the use of "character classes". The Pattern class provides a number of predefined character classes, as well as provides a facility to define custom character classes by enclosing characters, ranges of characters, or character classes in square brackets. Since character classes may be composed from other character classes, reb4j provides a separate class, CharClass, which contains static methods for working with character classes. Note that CharClass extends Regex, so instances may be used in any context in which a Regex would be valid.

Predefined Classes

The CharClass class provides constants that represent the various predefined character classes that the Pattern class supports. Examples of these include CharClass.PERL_DIGIT, which corresponds to the Perl-style regular expression "\d" (representing a digit), and CharClass.PERL_DIGIT, which corresponds to the POSIX named character class expression "\pAlnum". Consult the Javadocs for the complete list of available constants.

Lists of Characters

To define a character class that will match any of a series of characters, simply pass those characters as a String to the CharClass.characters method, which may optionally accept a boolean negate parameter to indicate that the character class should include all characters except the ones specified. 

final CharClass abc = CharClass.characters("abc");
final CharClass not123 = CharClass.characters("123", true);
Character Ranges

To define a character class that matches any characters whose ordinal values are between a minimum and maximum character (inclusive), use the CharClass.range method, which may also accept an optional negate parameter.

final CharClass a_thru_m = CharClass.range('a', 'm');
final CharClass notACapitalLetter = CharClass.range('A', 'Z', true);
Composing Character Classes

Instances of CharClass may be built from other instances.

Negation

To construct a character class that will match any character that is not in another character specified character class, use the CharClass.negate method.

final CharClass notALetter = CharClass.negate(CharClass.POSIX_ALPHA);
Union

To construct a character class that will match any character that would be matched by two or more other character classes, use the CharClass.union method.

final CharClass oneThruFive = CharClass.range('1, 5');
final CharClass threeThruEight = CharClass.range('3, '8');
final CharClass oneThruEight = CharClass.union(oneThruFive, threeThruEight);
Intersection

To construct a character class that will match only those characters that appear in all of several other character classes, use the CharClass.intersection method.

final CharClass vowels = CharClass.characters("AaEeIiOoUu");
final CharClass consonants = 
        CharClass.intersection(CharClass.POSIX_ALPHA, CharClass.negate(vowels));

Adopting Patterns

Sometimes it may be useful to include a regular expression that has already been compiled into a Pattern object as a sub-expression in an expression constructed by reb4j. This can be accomplished using the Regex.fromPattern method, which accepts a Pattern as an argument and constructs a new Regex from it.
